Terry Eastland, in *Ending Affirmative Action: The Case for Colorblind Justice*, states that "Most arguments for affirmative action fall into two categories: remedying past discrimination and promoting diversity." Eastland suggests that the policy's founders did not anticipate its benefits would largely accrue to those who did not need them, particularly middle-class minorities. She further argues that affirmative action carries a stigma, potentially fostering feelings of self-doubt and entitlement among minorities. Eastland views affirmative action as a significant risk with inconsistent returns, proposing that its absence would allow for freer individual competition.

Libertarian economist Thomas Sowell, in *Affirmative Action Around the World: An Empirical Study*, identifies several adverse effects of affirmative action. Sowell contends that such policies: encourage non-preferred groups to designate themselves as members of preferred groups to take advantage of group preference policies; primarily benefit the most fortunate within preferred groups (e.g., upper and middle-class blacks), often to the detriment of the least fortunate in non-preferred groups (e.g., poor white or Asian); reduce incentives for both preferred and non-preferred groups to perform at their best—the former due to lack of necessity, the latter due to potential futility—thereby leading to net societal losses; and engender animosity toward preferred groups (pp. 115–147).

The Royal Assent ceremony always unfolds in the Senate chamber, a tradition stemming from the fact that the monarch is historically barred from the House of Commons. When the day arrives, the Speaker of the Senate kicks things off by reading a notice from the Governor General's secretary, letting everyone know when the Governor General or their deputy will arrive. From that moment, the Senate cannot adjourn until the ceremony concludes.

Picture the scene: The Speaker moves to sit beside the throne, the Mace Bearer stands ready with the mace, and then the Governor General steps in to take the Speaker's chair. Next, the Speaker commands the Usher of the Black Rod to summon the Members of Parliament. Black Rod then leads them back to the Senate, with the Sergeant-at-Arms proudly carrying the House of Commons mace.

Inside the Senate, the MPs from the Commons gather behind the bar. Black Rod takes a spot beside the Governor General, who then simply nods to give Royal Assent to the presented bills – *these* bills, by the way, do NOT include appropriation bills. Once that list is complete, the Clerk of the Senate announces: "In Her Majesty's name, His [or Her] Excellency the Governor General [or the deputy] doth assent to these bills."

Now, if there *are* any appropriation bills needing assent, the Speaker of the House of Commons reads their titles. The Senate clerk repeats them to the Governor General, who again nods to signal Royal Assent. Finally, with all bills assented to, the Senate Clerk concludes by reciting: "In Her Majesty's name, His [or Her] Excellency the Governor General [or the deputy] thanks her loyal subjects, accepts their benevolence and assents to these bills." And with that, the Governor General or their deputy departs Parliament.

The early and mid-1980s plunged Libya into economic turmoil, its once-gushing oil revenues withering from a robust $21 billion in 1982 to a mere $5.4 billion by 1986, a devastating blow to the nation's coffers. Amidst this financial strain, Gaddafi’s audacious "Pet Project," the Great Man-Made River, began construction in 1983, a monumental irrigation scheme envisioned for completion by the decade's end yet still unfinished as the 21st century dawned, a testament to its colossal ambition and enduring challenge. Meanwhile, military spending surged, devouring resources as other vital administrative budgets were ruthlessly slashed.

Libya's shadow loomed large over neighboring Chad, where it had long fueled the FROLINAT militia. In December 1980, Libya brazenly re-invaded the war-torn nation at the behest of the Frolinat-controlled GUNT government, deepening its entanglement in the brutal civil war. Gaddafi, ever the provocateur, audaciously proposed a political merger just a month later. The Organisation of African Unity (OAU) swiftly condemned this overture, demanding a Libyan withdrawal, which grudgingly occurred in November 1981. Yet, as the civil war reignited, Libya plunged back in, its forces clashing directly with French troops aligned with southern Chadian factions.

A growing chorus of African nations had wearied of Libya's relentless meddling in foreign affairs; by 1980, nine states had severed diplomatic ties, and in a resounding public rebuke, the OAU cancelled its 1982 conference in Tripoli, effectively blocking Gaddafi's bid for chairmanship. In a bewildering twist, Gaddafi sought political unity with Morocco, culminating in the August 1984 signing of the Oujda Treaty with King Hassan II, forging the Arab-African Union. This alliance defied belief, given the profound political chasms and generations of bitter animosity separating the two regimes. LaserDisc audio could be stored in either analog or digital formats, often supporting various surround sound configurations. NTSC discs typically featured two analog audio tracks alongside two uncompressed PCM digital audio tracks, featuring a 16-bit depth and a 44.056 kHz sample rate. Conversely, PAL discs carried a single pair of audio tracks, which could be either analog or digital. The digital tracks on PAL discs featured 16-bit, 44.1 kHz sampling, mirroring compact disc specifications. Notably, in the UK, "LaserVision" designated discs with analog audio, while "LaserDisc" was reserved for those with digital audio. The digital audio signal in both formats was EFM-encoded, similar to compact discs.

Dolby Digital (also known as AC-3) and DTS, now common on DVD titles, first became available on LaserDisc. *Star Wars: Episode I – The Phantom Menace* (1999), released on LaserDisc in Japan, was among the earliest home video titles to incorporate 6.1 channel Dolby Digital EX Surround. Unlike DVDs, which carry Dolby Digital in a natively digital format, LaserDiscs stored this audio in a frequency-modulated form within a track typically designated for analog audio. Extraction of Dolby Digital from a LaserDisc necessitated a player featuring a dedicated "AC-3 RF" output, an external demodulator, and an AC-3 decoder. This demodulator was essential for converting the 2.88 MHz frequency-modulated AC-3 information from the disc into a 384 kbit/s signal compatible with the AC-3 decoder. When present, DTS audio superseded the standard digital audio tracks, and its playback merely required an S/PDIF-compliant digital connection to a DTS decoder.

Feynman's spacetime diagrams, depicting interactions among a limited set of particles, enabled him to model fundamental physics based on particle spins and the coupling ranges of fundamental forces. He subsequently proposed the parton model to explain the strong interactions governing nucleon scattering. This model developed as a complementary approach to the quark model conceived by his Caltech colleague, Murray Gell-Mann. The relationship between these two models was ambiguous; Gell-Mann, for instance, derisively termed Feynman's partons "put-ons." During the mid-1960s, quarks were widely regarded by physicists as merely a bookkeeping device for symmetry numbers rather than actual particles. This belief stemmed from the statistical paradox presented by the Omega-minus particle, whose interpretation as three identical strange quarks bound together appeared irreconcilable with the concept of real quarks. However, deep inelastic scattering experiments conducted at the Stanford Linear Accelerator in the late 1960s, analogous to Ernest Rutherford's 1911 experiment scattering alpha particles on gold nuclei, demonstrated that nucleons (protons and neutrons) contained point-like constituents responsible for electron scattering. While it was natural to identify these constituents with quarks, Feynman's parton model sought to interpret the experimental data without introducing additional hypotheses. Notably, the data indicated that approximately 45% of the nucleon's energy-momentum was carried by electrically neutral particles. These electrically neutral particles are now understood to be gluons, which mediate the strong force between quarks and possess the three-valued color quantum number that resolves the Omega-minus paradox. Despite the initial conceptual differences, Feynman did not fundamentally dispute the quark model. For instance, upon the discovery of the fifth quark in 1977, he promptly informed his students that this implied the existence of a sixth quark, which was subsequently discovered a decade after his passing.

In late 1203, John attempted to relieve Château Gaillard, a vital stronghold on Normandy's eastern flank then besieged by Philip. His synchronized operation, involving both land and water forces, was imaginative in concept but ultimately too complex for the period's military capabilities, and it was swiftly blocked by Philip's forces. John then retreated to Brittany, devastating the region in a bid to divert Philip from eastern Normandy; however, this failed to shift Philip's main advance. While historians' opinions on John's military skill during this campaign vary, most recent analyses deem his performance passable, though far from impressive.

John's position deteriorated rapidly. Years of extensive cultivation by Philip and his predecessors had strengthened Normandy's eastern border, while Angevin authority in the south had been weakened by Richard's earlier cession of key castles. Furthermore, John's reliance on routier mercenaries in central regions eroded his remaining local support, setting the stage for a swift collapse of Angevin power. In December, John retreated across the Channel, ordering the establishment of a new defensive line west of Château Gaillard. Yet, Gaillard fell in March 1204. The following month, his mother Eleanor died, a blow not only personal but threatening to unravel widespread Angevin alliances across southern France. Philip bypassed the new defenses, pushing deep into the Duchy's heart with minimal resistance. By August, Philip had seized Normandy, advancing south to occupy Anjou and Poitou, leaving John with only the Duchy of Aquitaine on the Continent.

Yet, in 2013, a pivotal study emerged, led by Martin B. Richards of the University of Huddersfield, weaving a different narrative of origins and once again substantiating the pre-2006 hypothesis. Delving into the very fabric of life, his team meticulously examined the full 16,600 units of mitochondrial DNA—a profound contrast to the mere thousand units previously sampled. This exhaustive exploration unveiled that the four primary female Ashkenazi founders had roots established in Europe between ten and twenty millennia ago, with most other minor founding lineages also tracing deep European ancestries. The research suggested that the vast majority of Ashkenazi maternal lines did not journey from the Near East, nor were they recruited from the Caucasus, but rather blossomed through assimilation within Europe, primarily from Italian and Old French sources. Richards, in summarizing the maternal findings, delivered a decisive blow to the "questionable, but still tenacious" Khazar hypothesis, asserting that no trace of mtDNA originated from the North Caucasus, and that all available studies "should thoroughly debunk" this persistent myth. Indeed, the 2013 study estimated that a striking eighty percent of Ashkenazi maternal ancestry flows from women indigenous to Europe, with only eight percent tracing to the Near East, the remaining threads yet to be fully charted. These findings, the study concluded, illuminate "a significant role for the conversion of women in the formation of Ashkenazi communities."

Exhibited at the 1912 Salon d'Automne, the architectural installation known as the Maison Cubiste (Cubist House), created by Raymond Duchamp-Villon and André Mare with a group of collaborators, presented a fascinating tension with contemporary Cubist theory. Concurrently, in *Du "Cubisme"*, Jean Metzinger and Albert Gleizes asserted the autonomous nature of art, emphatically stating that "decorative considerations should not govern the spirit of art." They deemed decorative work the "antithesis of the picture," arguing that "the true picture bears its raison d'être within itself. It can be moved from a church to a drawing-room, from a museum to a study. Essentially independent, necessarily complete, it need not immediately satisfy the mind: on the contrary, it should lead it, little by little, towards the fictitious depths in which the coordinative light resides. It does not harmonize with this or that ensemble; it harmonizes with things in general, with the universe: it is an organism..." Yet, Christopher Green notes that "Mare's ensembles were accepted as frames for Cubist works because they allowed paintings and sculptures their independence, creating a play of contrasts." This understanding facilitated the involvement of prominent Cubists, including Gleizes, Metzinger, Marie Laurencin, the Duchamp brothers (with Raymond Duchamp-Villon designing the facade), Fernand Léger, and Roger de La Fresnaye. The Maison Cubiste itself was a fully furnished dwelling, featuring a staircase, wrought iron banisters, a Salon Bourgeois displaying works by Marcel Duchamp, Metzinger's *Woman with a Fan*, Gleizes, Laurencin, and Léger, and a bedroom. It thus served as an example of *L'art décoratif*, a modern, bourgeois home designed to comfortably display Cubist art. Spectators at the Salon d'Automne traversed a full-scale 10-by-3-meter plaster model of Duchamp-Villon’s ground-floor facade. This architectural installation later traveled to the 1913 Armory Show in New York, Chicago, and Boston, listed in the New York catalogue as "Facade architectural, plaster" (Façade architecturale) by Raymond Duchamp-Villon.

Once primarily associated with folk and classical genres, the mandolin—often in its single-stringed electric form—has carved a distinctive niche within contemporary rock music. Tim Brennan of the Irish-American punk band Dropkick Murphys, for instance, integrates the mandolin alongside traditional Celtic instruments like the tin whistle and Great Highland bagpipes to enhance the band's signature growling sound. Similarly, the iconic 1991 R.E.M. hit "Losing My Religion" was notably driven by simple mandolin licks from guitarist Peter Buck, a technique he also employed in nearly a dozen other songs, helping the single reach No. 4 on the Billboard Hot 100 and top the rock and alternative charts. This versatility is further evident across a spectrum of rock artists: Luther Dickinson of North Mississippi Allstars and The Black Crowes has frequently incorporated the instrument, most notably on "Locust Street." Armenian American rock group System of A Down made extensive use of it on their 2005 double album *Mezmerize/Hypnotize*, while pop punk band Green Day featured it on several occasions, particularly on their 2000 album, *Warning*. Boyd Tinsley, violinist for the Dave Matthews Band, has utilized an electric mandolin since 2005. Frontman Colin Meloy and guitarist Chris Funk of The Decemberists regularly weave the mandolin into their band's intricate sound. Nancy Wilson, rhythm guitarist of Heart, famously played the mandolin on "Dream of the Archer" from *Little Queen* and on their cover of Led Zeppelin's "The Battle of Evermore." Even pop rock found a place for it, with Maria McKee's "Show Me Heaven," the theme song for the film *Days of Thunder*, prominently featuring the instrument.

In 1951, President Truman, reflecting a widespread desire for an Eisenhower candidacy, urged him to run for president as a Democrat. Eisenhower, however, voiced his disagreements with the Democratic Party, declaring himself and his family Republicans. A "Draft Eisenhower" movement within the Republican Party subsequently persuaded him to declare his candidacy in the 1952 presidential election, specifically to counter the non-interventionist Senator Robert A. Taft. Convincing Eisenhower was a protracted process; he needed assurance that political circumstances had created a genuine duty for him to run and that the populace desired him as president. His campaign manager, Henry Cabot Lodge, and others ultimately succeeded, leading to Eisenhower's resignation from his NATO command in June 1952 to campaign full-time. Eisenhower defeated Taft for the nomination, securing critical delegate votes from Texas. His campaign was noted for the simple but effective slogan, "I Like Ike." Crucial to his success was his expressed opposition to Roosevelt's Yalta policy and Truman's policies in Korea and China, despite his prior involvement in these matters. To appease the Republican Party's right-wing Old Guard after defeating Taft for the nomination, Eisenhower selected Richard M. Nixon as his Vice-Presidential running mate. Nixon also offered a strong anti-communist stance and a youthful presence to balance Eisenhower's age.

In 2006, Morgan Stanley embarked on an ambitious venture, acquiring 20 acres (8.1 ha) north of the Showboat Atlantic City Hotel and Casino with plans for a colossal $2 billion-plus casino resort. Revel Entertainment Group was entrusted with developing what would be known as the Revel Casino. However, the project was plagued from the start, suffering a crippling blow in April 2010 when Morgan Stanley, holding a 90% stake in Revel Entertainment Group, abruptly ceased funding for construction and put its interest up for sale. In a desperate bid to salvage the venture, the New Jersey state legislature passed a bill in early 2010 offering tax incentives to attract new investors. Yet, public skepticism was palpable; a March 2010 poll by Fairleigh Dickinson University's PublicMind revealed that three of five voters (60%) opposed the legislation, with two-thirds of those expressing "strong" opposition. Ultimately, Governor Chris Christie extended a controversial lifeline, offering Revel $261 million in state tax credits upon its opening. Against these odds, by March 2011, Revel had finally secured the necessary funding, completing its exterior and pressing forward with interior construction – a glimmer of hope for the troubled project. It tentatively opened its doors in April 2012, fully launching by May. But this brief respite was short-lived. A mere ten months later, in February 2013, after staggering losses and a dramatic write-down in its value from $2.4 billion to a mere $450 million, Revel inevitably filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy. A restructuring proved futile, and the doomed resort re-entered bankruptcy on June 19, 2014. Put up for sale, it found no suitable buyers, and so, unceremoniously, the

At the very heart of our identity, shaping every step we take, lies the often-fragile construct of self-esteem – that deep, visceral sense of our own worth and place in the world. It's a universal human yearning, a silent, persistent drive across all ages and genders, to nurture, defend, and elevate this inner core of self-worth. While the common narrative suggests a dramatic plummet during adolescence, our fundamental sense of self often remains remarkably resilient. Yet, the *barometric* shifts in our self-esteem – those sudden, volatile swings – can unleash a torrent of distress and anxiety, making the daily navigation of adolescence feel like an emotional tempest. Perhaps the very tools we use to measure this profound inner world miss the mark; broad, global scales often fail to capture the nuanced, deeply personal struggles and triumphs that truly define an adolescent's journey. For girls, self-esteem often blossoms in the fertile ground of supportive friendships, where the profound need for social and moral validation finds its deepest resonance. The sting of failing to win a friend's approval, the ache of not finding someone to share their inner world and passions with, can cast a long shadow, dimming their sense of self-worth and leaving them vulnerable. Boys, in stark contrast, often find their self-esteem forged in the fires of independence, in the assertive carving out of their place within authority structures. Their sense of value often soars with the ability to influence peers, to lead or command respect. Yet, the silent battle of romantic competence – the crushing blow of failing to win or hold the affection of another, regardless of orientation – can be a devastating assault on their inner fortitude, leaving their self-esteem in tatters. When the anchor of a romantic relationship is severed, both men and women find their self-esteem plunging into a void, leaving them profoundly susceptible to a cascade of painful

The Nintendo Entertainment System launched in North America with several distinct retail configurations, which evolved through various bundles over the ensuing years. Initially, the Deluxe Set retailed at US$199.99 (equivalent to approximately $475 in 2016) and included the R.O.B. accessory, an NES Zapper light gun, two controllers, and two Game Paks: *Gyromite* and *Duck Hunt*. A more affordable Basic Set, introduced in 1987, was available for US$89.99 without a game, or US$99.99 bundled with *Super Mario Bros.* Over the following years, Nintendo released additional themed bundles. In 1988, the Action Set, priced at US$149.99, included the console (often referred to as the Control Deck), two controllers, an NES Zapper, and a dual Game Pak featuring *Super Mario Bros.* and *Duck Hunt*. The 1989 Power Set provided the console, two controllers, an NES Zapper, a Power Pad, and a triple Game Pak containing *Super Mario Bros.*, *Duck Hunt*, and *World Class Track Meet*. In 1990, the Sports Set bundle offered the console, an NES Satellite infrared wireless multitap adapter, four controllers, and a dual Game Pak with *Super Spike V'Ball* and *Nintendo World Cup*. Two further bundles utilizing the original NES console model were released in 1992. The Challenge Set retailed for US$89.99, comprising the console, two controllers, and the *Super Mario Bros. 3* Game Pak. Concurrently, the Basic Set, which had initially appeared in 1987, was repackaged for US$89.99. This revised version included only the console and two controllers, no longer bundling a game cartridge. Instead, it featured the *Official Nintendo Player's Guide*, a comprehensive book detailing all NES games released up to that point.

A period of division for the Liberals followed, with former Treasurer John Howard competing with former Foreign Minister Andrew Peacock for party leadership. Concurrently, the Australian economy faced the early 1990s recession, with unemployment reaching 11.4% in 1992. In November 1991, under the leadership of Dr. John Hewson, the opposition launched the 650-page *Fightback!* policy document. This comprehensive package outlined a range of economically liberal measures, including the introduction of a Goods and Services Tax (GST), modifications to Medicare such as the abolition of bulk billing for non-concession holders, a nine-month limit on unemployment benefits, various industrial relations reforms including the abolition of awards, a $13 billion personal income tax cut primarily for middle and upper-income earners, $10 billion in government spending cuts, the abolition of state payroll taxes, and the privatization of numerous government-owned enterprises. These proposals represented a significant departure from the Keynesian economic conservatism practiced by previous Liberal/National Coalition governments.

The 15 percent GST served as the centerpiece of the policy document. Throughout 1992, Labor Prime Minister Paul Keating campaigned against the *Fightback* package, particularly the GST, which he characterized as an attack on the working class by shifting the tax burden from direct taxation of the wealthy to indirect, broad-based consumption tax. Significant pressure group activity and public opinion led Hewson to exempt food from the proposed GST, which subsequently raised questions about the complexity of defining food items to be exempt. Hewson's difficulties in explaining these complexities to the electorate were exemplified during the well-known "birthday cake interview," an event considered by some to be a turning point in the election campaign. Keating ultimately secured a record fifth consecutive Labor term in the 1993 election. While unsuccessful in its entirety, several *Fightback* proposals were later incorporated into law in various forms: to a minor extent during the Keating Labor government, and more substantially during the Howard Liberal government (most notably the GST). Furthermore, unemployment benefits and bulk billing provisions were revisited by the Abbott Liberal government.

The tyrannical Constantius, a staunch Arian who became sole ruler in 350 upon the death of his brother Constans, ruthlessly ordered the principled Liberius into exile in 356, granting him a mere three days to comply. Liberius was banished to the desolate Beroea in Thrace, but not before Constantius made a futile attempt to bribe him with lavish gifts—five hundred pieces of gold—contingent on his acceptance of the heretical Arian position. Liberius, a man of unwavering integrity, disdainfully refused, suggesting the emperor bestow such ill-gotten gains upon his sycophantic flatterers. He even rebuked the empress's messenger, urging them to embrace true faith rather than persecute God's Church. When the gifts were brazenly left in the Church, Liberius, in a magnificent display of defiance, cast them out.

Furious, Constantius had Liberius dragged under strict guard to Milan. There, in a legendary confrontation recorded by Theodoret, Liberius courageously stood his ground, reminding the emperor that Athanasius had been unequivocally acquitted at Sardica, his accusers exposed as pathetic calumniators and impostors. It was an unjust, unlawful condemnation. Though intellectually silenced, the emperor, seething with impotent rage, could only resort to tyranny, ordering Liberius back into exile.

Two years later, as Constantius grandiosely celebrated his twentieth year in Rome, the Roman ladies, moved by a rare display of public conscience, bravely petitioned for Liberius's return. Constantius, ever the manipulator, agreed, but only on the insidious condition that Liberius conform to the emperor's hand-picked, compliant bishops. Heartbreakingly, under immense pressure, Liberius subscribed to the condemnation of the sainted Athanasius—a beacon of unwavering orthodoxy—and accepted the insidious Arian creed framed at Sirmium. It was a moment of tragic compromise, a temporary yielding of principle. Yet, in a testament to his true convictions, no sooner had he regained his rightful see than he boldly and unequivocally reaffirmed his allegiance to the Nicene Creed, as Theodoret proudly records. On April 26, 1864, the U.S. Organic Act breathed life into the Montana Territory. Yet, even before this official birth, as families carved homes from the wild, the yearning for education took root. Humble subscription schools, often held within a teacher's own dwelling, became the first beacons of learning. The earliest formal lessons unfolded in 1862 at Fort Owen in the Bitterroot Valley, where Mr. Robinson guided the minds of Indian children and fort employees' offspring. His winter term, a brief spark, concluded by February's end. A year later, in 1863, Thomas Dimsdale ignited another subscription school in Virginia City, where knowledge came at the cost of $1.75 per week.

The Montana Territorial Legislative Assembly, gathering for its inaugural session in 1864, laid the bedrock for public education, empowering counties to levy taxes for schools. Madison County, quick to embrace this vision, pioneered the first public school in Virginia City in 1866. Though severe winter winds delayed its January opening until March, the school year, stretching through the nascent summer, finally concluded on August 17. Among its first guiding lights was Sarah Raymond, a spirited 25-year-old who had journeyed to Virginia City by wagon train in 1865. Her certification, a testament to frontier dedication, came after an in-home test and a $6 fee paid in gleaming gold dust. With Mrs. Farley as her assistant, Raymond bore the weight of 50 to 60 eager minds daily, out of 81 enrolled, earning $125 a month to Mrs. Farley's $75. No uniform textbooks graced their desks; instead, a treasured assortment of books, carried by emigrants on their long journeys, became their collective library. Though Sarah's time in the classroom ended the following year, her spirit of leadership continued, eventually guiding Madison County as its superintendent of schools, a true pioneer of education's enduring flame.

On 20 June 1794, Burke received a vote of thanks from the Commons for his services in the Hastings Trial and immediately resigned his seat, which his son, Richard, subsequently filled. Burke suffered a tragic blow with the loss of Richard in August 1794. Deeply devoted to his son, Burke perceived in him a promise not evident to others and, in retrospect, seemingly unfounded; however, this perception may have been colored by Richard's successful early work for Catholic emancipation. King George III, whose favour Burke had gained through his stance on the French Revolution, wished to create him Earl of Beaconsfield. However, his son's death rendered such an honour unappealing; consequently, the only award Burke accepted was a pension of £2,500. Even this modest pension was assailed by the Duke of Bedford and the Earl of Lauderdale. Burke responded to these criticisms in his *Letter to a Noble Lord* (1796), stating: "It cannot at this time be too often repeated; line upon line; precept upon precept; until it comes into the currency of a proverb, To innovate is not to reform." He contended that his own reward was merited, while the Duke of Bedford's wealth derived solely from inheritance, his ancestor being the original recipient of a royal grant. Burke contrasted their fortunes: "Mine was from a mild and benevolent sovereign; his from Henry the Eighth." The *Letter* further alluded to the potential consequences should their revolutionary ideas be implemented, and it contained a description of the British constitution.

The nation swiftly descended into civil war, marked by various factions often divided by clan loyalties. Over 500,000 residents fled, driven by persecution, deepening poverty, and the allure of better economic opportunities in the West or other former Soviet republics. Emomali Rahmon ascended to power in 1992, securing 58% of the vote against former Prime Minister Abdumalik Abdullajanov in the November presidential election. These elections followed swiftly after the war's conclusion, leaving Tajikistan utterly devastated. The conflict claimed an estimated 100,000 lives and displaced approximately 1.2 million people, both internally and as external refugees. In 1997, Rahmon and opposition parties reached a ceasefire, brokered by Gerd D. Merrem, Special Representative to the Secretary General, a widely lauded success for UN peacekeeping efforts. The ceasefire stipulated that 30% of ministerial posts would be allocated to the opposition. The 1999 elections, however, drew criticism from opposition parties and foreign observers who deemed them unfair, as Rahmon secured re-election with 98% of the vote. Rahmon again triumphed in the 2006 elections, securing 79% of the vote and commencing his third term. Despite a boycott by several opposition parties and criticism from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE), observers from the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) declared the elections legal and transparent. Rahmon's administration faced further OSCE criticism in October 2010 for its censorship and repression of media. The OSCE alleged the Tajik Government censored both domestic and foreign websites and conducted tax inspections on independent printing houses, effectively halting the operations of several independent newspapers.

Yale's enduring and often disproportionate representation in national politics since the Vietnam War has prompted a diverse array of explanations. At the heart of many theories lies the university's distinctive culture of engagement. Observers frequently cite the potent spirit of campus activism that galvanized Yale in the 1960s, alongside the formative intellectual influence of Reverend William Sloane Coffin on many aspiring politicians. Former President Richard Levin articulated this institutional ethos as Yale's deliberate commitment to functioning as "a laboratory for future leaders," a priority firmly established under the earlier presidencies of Alfred Whitney Griswold and Kingman Brewster. This dedication to civic life is echoed by Richard H. Brodhead, former dean of Yale College, who notes a profound institutional emphasis on "orientation to the community in our admissions" and a robust tradition of volunteerism. Yale historian Gaddis Smith further identifies a pervasive "ethos of organized activity" throughout the 20th century, exemplifying how figures like John Kerry, George Pataki, and Joseph Lieberman honed their leadership skills within the Yale Political Union and the Yale Daily News. Complementing this, Elisabeth Bumiller and James Fallows commend a unique culture of community and cooperation among students, faculty, and administration that actively downplays self-interest in favor of collective commitment. A more critical lens, however, focuses on the university's established social structures. Camille Paglia, for instance, attributes this political ascendancy to a pervasive "web of friendships and affiliations built up in school," indicative of entrenched networking and elitism. The last major building work occurred in 1913, during King George V's reign, when Sir Aston Webb refaced Blore's 1850 East Front with Portland stone. This new principal façade, designed to echo Giacomo Leoni's Lyme Park in Cheshire, now served as the grand backdrop for the Victoria Memorial, located outside the main gates. Ascending the throne in 1910, George V possessed a more serious temperament than his father, Edward VII, shifting the palace's focus from lavish parties to official entertaining and royal duties. He famously arranged a series of command performances, introducing jazz to the royal court with acts like the Original Dixieland Jazz Band in 1919—the first jazz performance for a head of state—followed by Sidney Bechet and Louis Armstrong in 1932. Such pioneering patronage later earned Buckingham Palace a 2009 nomination for a (Kind of) Blue Plaque from the Brecon Jazz Festival, recognizing its significant contribution to jazz music in the United Kingdom. His wife, Queen Mary, a true connoisseur of the arts, took a profound interest in the Royal Collection, dedicating herself to both restoring and augmenting its vast array of furniture and art. Among her many installations were a pair of 1810 marble Empire-style chimneypieces by Benjamin Vulliamy, which she placed in the ground floor Bow Room, the grand, low-ceilinged space at the heart of the garden façade. Queen Mary was also responsible for decorating the Blue Drawing Room, formerly the South Drawing Room, a 69-foot (21-meter) long space distinguished by Nash's specially designed coffered ceiling with its massive gilt console brackets.

The departures of Núñez and van Gaal were utterly overshadowed by the seismic exit of Luís Figo, then the club's vice-captain. Figo had ascended to cult hero status, embraced by Catalans as one of their own. Yet, Barcelona fans were left utterly betrayed and incandescent with rage by Figo's defection to arch-rivals Real Madrid. During his subsequent visits to the Camp Nou, Figo was met with an unprecedented torrent of hostility. His infamous first return saw a piglet's head and a full bottle of whiskey hurled at him from the furious crowd. The subsequent three years plunged the club into a precipitous decline, marked by a revolving door of managers. Van Gaal's successor, Llorenç Serra Ferrer, despite a lavish investment in players during the summer of 2000, presided over a truly mediocre league campaign and a humiliating first-round Champions League exit, leading to his dismissal late in the season. Long-serving coach Carles Rexach was appointed, initially on a temporary basis, and managed to salvage a Champions League berth on the final day. Despite improved form in La Liga and a respectable run to the Champions League semi-finals, Rexach was never seen as a long-term solution. That summer, Louis van Gaal returned for his second spell. What followed, despite another decent Champions League performance, was one of the worst La Liga campaigns in the club's history, with the team plummeting as low as 15th in February 2003. This catastrophic performance led to van Gaal's resignation and his replacement by Radomir Antić for the remainder of the season, though he could only manage a meager sixth-place finish. At season's end, Antić's short-term contract was not renewed, and club president Joan Gaspart resigned, his position rendered completely untenable by a disastrous season that capped a three-year decline in the club's fortunes since his presidency began.
